item.title: Myanmar Approves Cabinet Nominees, but Some Face Questions Over Credentials
item.description: Two of the picks list academic achievements from dubious institutions, prompting questions of the new government’s credibility.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: U Kyaw Win, who is expected to be the new minister of finance and planning, said he earned a master’s degree and a doctorate from Brooklyn Park University. But that institution has been identified as part of a network of websites run by a Pakistan-based company that has sold millions of dollars in fake diplomas.

item.title: Radovan Karadzic, a Bosnian Serb, Gets 40 Years Over Genocide and War Crimes
item.description: The United Nations tribunal for the former Yugoslavia convicted Mr. Karadzic of genocide for the Srebrenica massacre but acquitted him of other charges.
item.category: International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Robin Van Lonkhuijsen
item.media:description: Radovan Karadzic, second from right, at the United Nations tribunal for the former Yugoslavia in The Hague on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Indicts 7 Iranians in Cyberattacks on Banks and a Dam
item.description: The indictment is the first time that the Obama administration has sought action against Iranians for a wave of computer attacks that began in 2011.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Inventing the Irish
item.description: At the Easter Rising centenary, Ireland should look past national mythology to see its shared history with Britain.
item.dc:creator: BARRY KENNERK
item.media:credit: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
item.media:description: The remains of the Dublin Bread Company, after the Easter Rising in 1916. The weeklong rebellion has become the cornerstone of Ireland’s national story.

item.title: Salah Abdeslam, Suspect in Paris Attacks, Seeks Extradition to France
item.description: Mr. Abdeslam, captured in Belgium, reversed his position after the bombings in Brussels, which killed at least 31 and wounded about 300 on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers outside the Brussels courthouse where Salah Abdeslam, a suspect in the Paris attacks, appeared on Thursday. The hearing was postponed until April 7.

item.title: Syrian Forces and ISIS Clash at Edge of Palmyra
item.description: Government troops and allied militias, backed by intensive Russian airstrikes, are fighting to retake the city, along with its majestic ancient ruins.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: New Zealand, Unmoved by Bionic Kiwi and Starry-Eyed Sheep, Keeps Its Flag
item.description: The judges weighed 10,292 options and the country spent two years thinking about it, but in the end the vote was decisively for the century-old ensign.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: A nationwide postal vote pitted the incumbent flag, foreground, against a design known as the Silver Fern (Black, White and Blue), background. Early results indicated that 56.6 percent favored the existing flag.

item.title: Kerry Says Brussels Attacks Renew Urgency for U.S.-Russia Efforts in Mideast
item.description: John Kerry, in Moscow, said that some progress had been made in Syria, but that a further reduction in violence and increased humanitarian aid were needed.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met with his Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov, in Moscow, on Thursday.

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Jason Y. Ng on Aftermath of Hong Kong’s Umbrella Revolution
item.description: He says while the 2014 protests failed to gain any concessions from Beijing, social justice has now replaced social status on the people’s list of priorities.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Dale De La Rey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators held up their phones near the Hong Kong government headquarters on Sept. 29, 2014, around the start of the Occupy movement.

item.title: Kabul Journal: Buttressing a ‘Wall of Kindness’ Against a Harsh Reality in Afghanistan
item.description: Brightly decorated donation walls have spread rapidly from country to country, but the youths who created the Afghan capital’s wall have run into endless frustration.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Abdul Latif, 17, Sakina Saidi, 14, and Ali Roman, 16, in front of their Wall of Kindness in Kabul, Afghanistan, this month.

item.title: North Korea Tests New Rocket Engine, State Media Says
item.description: The test of the design, a solid-fuel rocket engine, would decrease the time needed to prepare the launch of a missile, defense officials said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Travelers at a train station in Seoul, South Korea, watching a broadcast of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, observing what the North called a test of new solid-fuel rocket engine.

item.title: Sinosphere: German President Presses China on Political Prisoners During Visit
item.description: The president, Joachim Gauck, used a five-day state visit to raise human rights issues with Chinese leaders, his spokeswoman said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: President Joachim Gauck of Germany meeting with students after his speech at Tongji University in Shanghai on Wednesday.

item.title: Chinese Lawyer Detained While Defending Churches Is Reported Released
item.description: It was unclear whether Zhang Kai, who was detained in August while fighting the removal of crosses from churches, had been released on bail pending a trial.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: The lawyer Zhang Kai appeared last month in a locally televised video in which he said he had worked with foreign groups to stir up trouble over religion.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Can the European Center Hold?
item.description: The Brussels attacks may be the last step toward the dissolution of the dream of Continental integration.
item.dc:creator: JOCHEN BITTNER

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Terrorists, Bathtubs and Snakes
item.description: Brussels survived this week’s terror attacks, but it may not survive climate change.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS KRISTOF
item.media:description: Most of the almost fifty large glaciers in the Los Glaciares National Park in Argentina have been retreating over the past fifty years due to warming temperatures, according to the European Space Agency (ESA).

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Dangerous World, Serious Leaders
item.description: Bombast is hollow, braggadocio is meaningless. This country needs its most stable and steady hands to guide it.
item.dc:creator: CHARLES M. BLOW

item.title: Brussels Attack Victim, Olivier Delespesse, Remembered as a Devoted Colleague
item.description: A co-worker of Mr. Delespesse, 45, a civil servant, described him as “very playful” and “someone who was deeply interested in people.”
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Olivier Delespesse in a photograph taken from social media.

item.title: Brothers Among 3 Brussels Suicide Attackers; Another Assailant Is Sought
item.description: Ibrahim el-Bakraoui attacked the airport and his brother Khalid attacked the subway, Belgian officials said, as an inquiry drew links to the 2015 Paris attacks.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN, KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA and AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Debris Is Probably From Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, Investigators Say
item.description: The Australian authorities said that two pieces of debris found in Mozambique were very likely to have come from the missing jetliner.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: One of the two pieces of aircraft debris found in Mozambique on March 3. The pieces arrived in Australia this week, and experts have begun analyzing them, Australian officials said.

item.title: World Briefing: Vietnam: 2 Sentenced Over Blog Posts
item.description: The blogger was sentenced to five years in prison, and his assistant to three years, after a court ruled that they were guilty of abuses of their freedom and infringements upon state interests.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
